awd_titl_txt: Improving Science, Technology and Math Programs at Little Priest Tribal College
awd_abstract_narration:
Little Priest Tribal College's (LPTC) "Improving Science, Technology and Math
Programs at Little Priest Tribal College" (ISTAMP) project seeks funding that will
improve in-class and program retention, increase the intensity of the support methods
used with students, change teaching methods in order to make the college's science
programs more exciting, develop an internship program that hooks students into
undergraduate research, and initiate the development of a Geographic Information
Systems, Geographic Positioning System, and Visualization associate degree program.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Little Priest Tribal College’s TCUP grant award, Improving Science, Technology and Math Programs at LPTC, has
supported LPTC’s efforts to enhance STEM educational opportunities for its
students. And, although the grant has undergone slight changes in scope, the
goals of the grant have remained consistent, which are to attract and engage
current and future students in STEM-related majors and courses. The following
overview explains the core concepts and scope of the award.



    
Goal one: “to increase recruitment, enrollment, and retention in STEM
courses and programs.” This initiative has seen successes and, more
importantly, it continues to grow in capacity. From its inception, a STEM
recruiter, retention specialist and advanced skills lab instructors were hired,
and infrastructure materials for a skills lab were purchased and installed.
Library resource materials were upgraded and LPTC began offering dual
enrollment classes at the local high school. These initiatives continued to be
strengthened (i.e. expansion of recruiter’s efforts, youth and community
workshops, summer science camps, hiring of tutors for learning lab, etc.)
throughout the time of the award, and most years saw increases in enrollment
and retention for our STEM courses.[1]
In 2013, a Summer Bridge Program in math, English and technology began, which
has helped to recruit high school students into LPTC programs.



    
Goal two, “to improve the quality of STEM courses by cultural infusion,
experiential and research projects,” has also been successful. An ongoing
program of professional development opportunities emphasizing cultural
integration was initiated and participated in by faculty and staff. This was
especially important for newly hired employees. Additionally, the award allowed
for an increase of cultural integration within LPTC’s courses, to include
redesigned content, new modes of delivery, incorporation of Native Case
Studies, guest speakers and community service projects. Presently, all LPTC
courses (not just STEM courses) require cultural integration. Other
improvements in STEM course quality have also occurred, such as the
implementation of new math software, experiential learning activities, research
projects, and both increased and more efficient use of technology. For example,
students in multimedia courses are now recording powwows and other
culturally-relevant community activities; then, editing and broadcasting them
on LPTC’s radio station which has been converted to all Native content.



    
Goal three, “to strengthen STEM foundation courses and LPTC’s capacity
to deliver STEM offerings”, is closely related to the other goals of this
grant. It includes professional development, cultural integration, experiential
learning, development of the learning lab and hiring of STEM tutors, as
mentioned above. However, this grant has also allowed LPTC to hire new
STEM-related faculty members in math, science, computers, multimedia and
alternate energy; redesign and revise existing STEM programs and their courses,
including our developmental math program; and offer new STEM courses, which has
increased enrollment
in STEM-related programs. The award has also allowed the purchase of materials
and equipment in order to ensure our STEM curriculum meets the needs of
students in the digital age.

in STEM-related programs. The award has also allowed the purchase of materials

students in the digital age.





    
Goal four, "to deliver a GIS/GPS visualization degree program that
supports the environmental STEM foci at LPTC" has seen a strong beginning.
Computers capable of handling this program have been purchased and installed,
library materials were acquired, a faculty member for the program was hired and
networking with local universities has begun. (Note: This goal was revised in
2009 to increase number of high school graduates enrolling in LPTC, which ties
into the outcomes of Goal one of this report).
